review_title: A poor company to work for
pros: Big name with a long proud history of innovation. Research departments and technical innovation are inspiring and might be able to win big again in the future.
cons:
My experiences have not been good with IBM. This is a company that was once a market leader, but is struggling to make the connection with the changing needs of a digital world. And they are panicking. This results in continuous changing priorities, reorganizations, mass-layoffs, broken processes, frustrated customers, and deceiving managers saying one thing but doing something else.
Some might have a grand time at IBM and be safe from the politics that is going on, but for anyone considering a job in IT I would just say this. You deserve better!

review_title: Lagging behind other Big Tech firms in multiple ways & dimensions
pros:
— Decent benefits 
— Good diversity
— Nice campus (Hursley, UK)
cons:
— A lot of red-tape and bureaucracy.

— Very few internal opportunities for growth. Moving teams is virtually impossible, which means there is very little talent reshuffling. Most of the graduates leave the moment their graduate scheme is over, which means that IBM loses its best talent (judging from how difficult it is to get the role), and loses the 2 year investment. How's that logical to anyone in senior management baffles everyone around. 

— Moves very slowly and has incredible difficulties keeping up with Amazon and Microsoft. The burden of legacy outweighs the benefits of a 100+ years long experience.

— Looking from inside, I would definitely not bet any money on the long-term growth of the company. In fact, I would short the stock. Warren Buffett seems to agree.

— Too slow to innovate, too slow to fire, too slow to adapt. Simply, too slow.

— Amazon's valuation is 15th times higher (as of February 2021), whilst they have 1/10 of the patents that IBM has. What does that tell you? That you don't win in the market by collecting patents for the sake of collecting patents - what a waste of brainpower and money. You win in the market by being smart about the industries/products you go all in for. During the last ten years, the world has seen one of the longest periods of wonderful market returns in the stock market (look at any big tech company, apart from IBM) - if you invested in IBM, you would have lost 50% of your portfolio, since that has been the absolute return since 2010-2012 peak. Sweet.

— The company's agility is similar to the agility of someone same age as IBM.

review_title: IBM is the place for upskilling and ongoing learning
pros: The learning opportunities never stop. The online learning platform is rich with content for your current job and potential future ones. The layout is very user friendly. cons:
Mainly I see 2 Cons. 1st is leave policy and 2nd is Promotions
Leave policy: As per IBM, there are 22 leaves per year and 12 will be carry forwarded. But there is a stupid policy in IBM called utilization. Because of this we cannot take those 22 leaves. Instead we can take only 15 leaves.
2. Promotion: I ate the promotion process in IBM. Management will say that we need to be there in a band for min of 2 years. But I'm in same band from more than 3 years and still I didn't get promotion. If you are a fresher please don't even think about IBM.

job_title: Advisory IT Architect in Vancouver, BC
pros:
- The corporate culture encourages employees to learn and grow.
- People are friendly and supportive. Newcomers are offered to get "buddies" and "mentors" to speed up the onboarding.
- Access to experts of any area inside the company. You may not know them, but they are there - when you find them, you are in good hands.
- Awsome learning opportunities. Access to internal company assets, reference architectures, documentation, classes in addition to external tools (O'Reilly, Udemy, etc.).
cons:
- Some processes require time because of additional approvals and loops.
- A lot of information, easy to get lost because you get too much information and spend a lot of time filtering/analyzing.
- Getting on a new project might look like an "internal hire" with sending CVs, interviews, decisions.

job_title: Applications Developer Apprentice in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: A good group of people to work with at the peer level.
cons:
Questionable behavior from management.

Covid 19 made a difficult situation for everyone at every level of work (which is why this is a 2 star review and not a 1 star).

For the apprenticeship in BR, you're promised to learn a variety of IT skills over the course of a year--it's a written document with a fairly unambiguous skills list. What I experienced was an implicit pressure to learn the tools relevant to the team I was working under, and forego learning anything unrelated. The plan seemed to be to just get some quick videos to watch that direct management could verify were reviewed and then check a box.

Speaking to different levels of management about it felt like I was being brushed off (though in a very polite manner).

Once covid 19 really started to take off, apprentices were placed on a, "project," involving the unemployment claims systems along with other IBM organizations. We were initially told we would be rotated out in a month, and we would still have the time to work on our apprentice material.

The month came and went. Those promises left with it, and so did I. 

The pandemic situation has been dynamic, so I can't blame anyone for not knowing how long it would last or moving the goal post so to speak. However, the BR apprenticeship seemed like a means of gathering unsuspecting individuals with the hope of a future in IT, and locking them into a low pay role for an extended period. 

Those with talent and free time would build their skills on their own time, and eventually move on to a location where they can make 2 or 3 times as much money. Those without, would be stuck.

pros:
The best part of working at IBM is it's people. They hire smart, passionate individuals, who help each other succeed. A growth mindset is crucial to have at IBM. You will learn so much about technology and each other!

It's easy to find side projects to grow your skills & portfolio, and you'll need to do that.
cons:
There is no real upward movement. Unfortunately due to the sheer amount of staff, management doesn't have proper headcount or allowance to allow for promotions. This means that more senior designers eventually leave for other organizations, or are removed with yearly layoffs.

Also, due to the kinds of work you do, you might not have anything in a portfolio to show for it. This is common knowledge among management, but no one in leadership roles attempts to fix this challenge, probably because they're overloaded elsewhere.
